SubTopics: Describe how a particular story's or drama's plot unfolds in a series of episodes as well as how the characters respond or change as the plot moves toward a resolution.
Content: Read these sentences from paragraph 13.
:box:ùêµùëñùëî ùëôùëñùëòùëí ùëé ùëôùëíùëöùëöùëñùëõùëî. Aaluk laughed. Tupaaq laughed, too, which made my cheeks grow warm.

SubTopics: Analyze how a particular sentence, chapter, scene, or stanza fits into the overall structure of a text and contributes to the development of the theme, setting, or plot.
Content: The main reason the author uses italics in the passage is to

A.Choice: signal changes of setting.

B.Choice: indicate important information.

C.Choice: show when a character speaks.

D.Choice: introduce words from other languages.

A.Choice: People drumming

B.Choice: Flags waving

C.Choice: Babies squealing

D.Choice: Dogs barking

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: In paragraph 19, why does the narrator describe the song by saying she is ‚Äúhearing it as if with new ears‚Äù?

A.Choice: She has never heard this song before.

B.Choice: The song has more meaning for her this time.

C.Choice: She is unfamiliar with the words in the song.

D.Choice: The song is louder than ever before.

SubTopics: Cite textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Why is the narrator forbidden to ride with Tupaaq?

A.Choice: The narrator's grandmother is angry at Tupaaq.

B.Choice: Tupaaq plans to invite the narrator's sister instead.

C.Choice: Tupaaq's boat is too crowded to carry the narrator.

D.Choice: The narrator is too young to ride in Tupaaq's boat.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: In paragraph 15, the narrator says ‚Äúthe women's voices, clear as water‚Äù most likely to reveal that

A.Choice: the sound is perfect and pure.

B.Choice: the words are simple and familiar.

C.Choice: the women sing near the shore.

D.Choice: the women are visible from a great distance.

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
Content: Which sentence best illustrates the main idea of the article?

A.Choice: ‚ÄúOne of the more common Sonoran Desert plants is the creosote bush.‚Äù

B.Choice: ‚ÄúThe Sonoran Desert is an arid region covering 120,000 square miles in southwestern Arizona, southeastern California and parts of Mexico.‚Äù

C.Choice: ‚ÄúMore than 400 edible plants grow in the Sonoran Desert and many of these plants can be used as medicines.‚Äù

D.Choice: ‚ÄúIt is illegal to go out and gather these natural plants today because many of them are protected by the Arizona Native Plant Law; however, with special permission, many of these plants are now sold in ethnic grocery stores in Arizona.‚Äù

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and explain how it is conveyed in the text.
Content: The main purpose of paragraphs 1‚Äì3 is most likely to

A.Choice: present information that readers need to understand the article.

B.Choice: introduce a problem and solution that help readers visualize the setting.

C.Choice: present an unexpected situation that captures readers' attention.

D.Choice: introduce a relationship between a mother and son that appeals to readers' emotions.

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and explain how it is conveyed in the text.
Content: Which sentence best illustrates the author's opinion?

A.Choice: ‚ÄúOne of the more common Sonoran Desert plants is the creosote bush.‚Äù

B.Choice: ‚ÄúThe most remarkable use for the prickly pear cactus was to control the blood sugar levels in diabetics.‚Äù

C.Choice: ‚ÄúThere is no part of the mesquite tree that cannot be used as a medicine.‚Äù

D.Choice: ‚ÄúBecause there are so many medicinal uses for the creosote bush, scientists and botanists are still learning what this plant can do.‚Äù

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, distinguishing claims that are supported by reasons and evidence from claims that are not.
Content: Which sentence helps support the author's claim that the Sonoran Desert ‚Äúis considered a natural pharmacy‚Äù?

A.Choice: ‚ÄúAmazingly, the creosote can live up to two years without water.‚Äù

B.Choice: ‚ÄúThe creosote has been known to help cure colds, stomach cramps and to heal wounds and burns.‚Äù

C.Choice: ‚ÄúThe creosote is a tough little plant, too.‚Äù

D.Choice: ‚ÄúThe Spanish explorers who first came to the Sonoran Desert called the creosote 'Little Stinker' because of the thick, sweet odor the plants emit after a rain storm.‚Äù

SubTopics: Cite textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: In the past, how did the native people of the Sonoran Desert determine which plants were safe for humans?

A.Choice: They used trial and error.

B.Choice: They learned from their ancestors.

C.Choice: They tried the plants on animals first.

D.Choice: They studied how the plants affected the environment.

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and explain how it is conveyed in the text.
Content: Vicks is a strong-smelling medicine currently used to treat colds and congestion.
Read this quotation from paragraph 9.
:box:A pre-historic Vicks!
The author included this quotation most likely to

A.Choice: explain in detail how the plant helps loosen nasal passages.

B.Choice: provide a sensory description of the scent of the creosote bush when boiled.

C.Choice: add humor to maintain interest while relating the material to modern times.

D.Choice: explain a benefit of the creosote bush while providing a distraction from the facts.

SubTopics: Cite textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Why is the mesquite tree known as the desert's ‚Äútree of life‚Äù?

A.Choice: Bean pods of the tree were used as nourishing food.

B.Choice: The tree grows in the desert where nothing else will grow.

C.Choice: Clear sap from the tree was used to relieve sore throats.

D.Choice: The native peoples use all parts of the tree to survive in the desert.

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and explain how it is conveyed in the text.
Content: The author would most likely agree that

A.Choice: native peoples appreciate living in the desert.

B.Choice: native plants treat illnesses better than modern medicines.

C.Choice: surviving in deserts is difficult without careful study of native plants.

D.Choice: using native plants to treat illnesses is a wise use of natural resources.

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and explain how it is conveyed in the text.

C.Choice: relate Diwali to American holidays.

D.Choice: compare American foods to those eaten during Diwali.

SubTopics: Cite textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: How is celebrating Diwali different in the United States than in India?

A.Choice: The meal is more complex in the United States.

B.Choice: The diya candles burn a shorter time in the United States.

C.Choice: The festival is a shorter length in the United States.

D.Choice: The festival clothing is more formal in the United States.

Content: Which sentence from the article best supports the subheading ‚ÄúTraditional Indian Dress‚Äù?

A.Choice: ‚ÄúEsha and her mom do many special things to get ready.‚Äù

B.Choice: ‚ÄúA long dupatta (DOO-pa-ta) or scarf, drapes over the neck in a complementary color and design.‚Äù

C.Choice: ‚ÄúAfter everyone is dressed, the family gathers for the puja (POO-ja) or prayers at home.‚Äù

D.Choice: ‚ÄúBoth Indian and American children perform traditional dances before the entire school body.‚Äù 6

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and explain how it is conveyed in the text.
Content: Which sentence best reveals the author's attitude about the celebration of Diwali?

B.Choice: ‚ÄúDiwali is also a time to celebrate with food.‚Äù

:box:The winter feast continues when the oldest family member gathers all the visitors and recites poetry, tells fortunes and stories.

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and explain how it is conveyed in the text.
Content: How are the purposes of ‚ÄúDiwali: The Indian Festival of Lights‚Äù and ‚ÄúCelebrate Light in the Dark‚Äù similar?

A.Choice: They entertain with stories of how families celebrate together.

B.Choice: They attempt to persuade readers to celebrate specific holidays.

C.Choice: They describe cultural festivals in which light is important.

D.Choice: They inform readers about ways that people have historically used light.

SubTopics: Analyze in detail how a key individual, event, or idea is introduced, illustrated, and elaborated in a text (e.g., through examples or anecdotes).
Content: According to the articles, how do the people of the two cultures compare regarding their use of light during their celebrations?

A.Choice: Indians believe light attracts the goddess of wealth; Iranians believe light chases darkness away.

B.Choice: Indians and Iranians believe light protects them from danger in the darkness.

C.Choice: Indians believe light brings blessings; Iranians believe light improves health.

D.Choice: Indians and Iranians believe light brings knowledge.

SubTopics: Cite textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: The articles are similar because they

A.Choice: include information about traditional dress.

B.Choice: provide details about school celebrations.

C.Choice: include foods that symbolize prosperity.

D.Choice: develop positive attitudes about the culture.
